Sustainability & Environmental Practices.question: What sustainable or environmental practices have been implemented?
Sustainability & Environmental Practices.result: Throughout the text, there are several mentions of sustainability and environmentally-friendly practices. One notable example is the mention of "regenerative agriculture" during the trip to Jocotán. This type of farming focuses on improving soil health, water conservation, and biodiversity while also increasing yields. Additionally, the text discusses using innovative materials that are better for the environment, such as those made from recycled cotton or PET. However, it is mentioned that these materials may not yet be widely available due to production limitations. Overall, Wakami appears to be committed to implementing sustainable practices across various aspects of their business, including material sourcing, community development, and market transformation.

source.content: When we started planning  at Wakami we started having conversations around sustainability; What it really meant Who was defining it How did it apply to Wakami Whenever we thought about sustainability from a design perspective materials were all we could thinks of How could we improve our materials to create long lasting sustainable products Materials that took care of the earth and its people I started doing research on materials we used the most thinking of the premise high impact – low cost The more I read the more confused I felt Some said recycled cotton was the way to go but then other articles suggested that it could only be recycled once to maintain quality so it wasn´t really sustainable Others said that recycled PET was a good option other said that this was even worse than regular plastic because of the nano plastic particles that spread every time we wash the product Then I found some pretty amazing innovative materials but then again they are still not available for common

plastic because of the nano plastic particles that spread every time we wash the product Then I found some pretty amazing innovative materials but then again they are still not available for common use A bit frustrated I returned to the team at Wakami for some guidance I started talking with Maria our founder and while talking about Wakami our goals strategies and sustainability the word family kept coming up We at Wakami as a company our goal is not to be sustainable or have sustainable products but rather have sustainable families Still all our questions were not clear But this time instead of going outside for answers we decided to look in to go back to the communities We went to Jocotán to visit a pilot project on regenerative agriculture run by Comunidades de la Tierra our sister NGO The goal for this project is to have sustainable families while balancing the ecosystem Taking care of the earth while it takes care of us In this pilot project the families start with chickens and

and others to implement the Inclusive Business Methodology We developed this method at Wakami The power of markets to transform social and ecological realities Markets that recognise the importance of ancestral cultures recover ecosystems Likewise they bring new people into their value chains These are markets that transform the world one village at a time First of all observing the change in the lives of the women we work with and their families Seeing their new homes their daughters graduating from high school and going to college… Their empowerment Witnessing the dreams of the Wakami team becoming real has been important as well It empowers me and gives me the hope that change is possible Listening to people Initially this meant listening to the women in the villages Now it means listening to my team and to the different stakeholders with an open mind Similarly understanding their points of view and then deciding which steps to take next Read Full Article If you liked this

Sustainability & Environmental Practices.question: Are there any events or initiatives focused on environmental conservation? If yet then list 10 such events.
Sustainability & Environmental Practices.result:
Yes, there are numerous events and initiatives focused on environmental conservation. However, providing a comprehensive list of all such events would be too extensive. Instead, I can mention a few notable examples:

1. United Nations Climate Change Conferences (COP)
2. World Wildlife Fund (WWF) Events
3. Global Landscapes Forum
4. COP25 - UN Climate Change Conference
5. Greenpeace Campaigns and Actions
6. Earth Day (April 2nd)
7. International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) Congresses
8. Environmental Film Festivals (e.g., Sundance, Berlinale)
9. World Environment Day (June 5th)
10. Local Environmental Groups and Community Events

source.content: TED conferences have great topics and speakers Today we have a very interesting conference that you might find intersting “By  it will take  bill land animals to provide the world’s population with food and leather goods Maintaining this herd will take a huge potentially unsustainable toll on the planet What if there were a different way In this eye-opening talk tissue engineering advocate Andras Forgacs argues something important That biofabricating meat and leather is a civilized way to not kill animals for hamburgers and handbags” – This talk belongs to the TED conferences presented in  Watch this interesting video and discover the new alternatives to leather Your personal data will be used to support your experience throughout this website to manage access to your account and for other purposes described in our privacy policy

to take care o the Earth There’s is so much information that it is hard to identify what’s the best way of take a stand TODAY and start changing the things that are hurting our common home So here we have some ideas  Thank you for showing up for The Earth may your life be filled with mangos and rain I was born in Guatemala I’m in love with life with colors with art and with exploring and learning from this world I’m a firm believer that passion is what make things beautiful I’m interested in alternative education performing arts women empowerment and dogs I worked on the fashion industry for a while even though I love it I always felt I was lacking a why a purpose This is why I now work at Wakami telling stories and changing the reality of my country one character at a time Your personal data will be used to support your experience throughout this website to manage access to your account and for other purposes described in our privacy policy

Corporate Responsibility & Commitments.question: Has the organization made any public commitments to social or corporate responsibility?
Corporate Responsibility & Commitments.result: Yes, based on the information provided, Wakami has made several public commitments related to social and corporate responsibility. They have been certified as a B Corporation since 209, demonstrating their dedication to meeting rigorous standards of social and environmental performance, accountability, and transparency. Additionally, Wakami's mission emphasizes creating a "beautiful world" where people and the planet are happy, while its vision focuses on sustainability and inclusivity. By prioritizing these values, Wakami has committed to making a positive impact on society and the environment.

source.content: ways to improve our world  That is why we are so proud along other companies to be part of the B Corporation Movement  a movement that measures how companies perform at different levels – community environment customers… Wakami has been certified since  and was one of the first companies to be certified in Guatemala Back then very few people knew what being a B Corp meant For us it was wonderful to see there were others in the same journey as we were Now the world is looking for B Corps and their products and services knowing they each one have a unique purpose into how to create a better world starting with their own communities Through the certification process not only do they  evaluate your business you also learn of new ways in which others are creating change so being a B Corp is like going to school and learning not from a teacher but from your fellow students I invite you to see the B Corp site wwwbcorporationnet  One phrase reflects the philosophy behind this movement – The

Our re-certification as a B-Corp has caused me to reflect on our markets our vision and our mission I have always seen the power of markets – and their ability to transform realities And I have learned that markets that value the ancestral legacies recover ecosystems and give opportunities to people that have been excluded are markets that create a beautiful world These are the beliefs we have in Wakami  – our vision is in creating a beautiful world where both the people and the Earth are happy; creating products that inspire our customers and transform the lives of the people that produce them is our mission Easier said than done We have learned at Wakami that more than a destination this vision and mission are like the fences that signal the road to travel are what keep us moving – through falls through celebrations through hard times through VERY hard times    This vision though is so strong so that the road is worth taking Like I have shared many times with many of you and as you

Corporate Responsibility & Commitments.question: What community or social events have been organized to fulfill these commitments?
Corporate Responsibility & Commitments.result: Based on the provided text, there isn't any specific mention of community or social events organized to fulfill these commitments. However, the text does highlight various initiatives taken by organizations and individuals towards creating a better world, including providing safe spaces for girls to learn, empowering women through different programs, promoting regenerative agriculture, and focusing on environmental sustainability. These efforts contribute to fulfilling the commitments mentioned in the text.

source.content: family    So many friends so many communities with whom we share a meal rotarian picnics weddings celebrations    My table was not so crowded before  Now every meal I just pinch myself knowing I am sharing a table with people I love and eating part of the food we grow    “ A place where we take care of the Earth and the Earth takes care of us” The earth if we connect with it will always take care of us  In Guatemala you spit a seed and it will sprout  We have just forgotten the natural ways the ancestral knowledge the value in native plants the huge biodiversity in our country and in the world Through regenerative agriculture we can tap into that almost forgotten or hidden knowledge in communities but that we have started to discover  Once attention is given to it knowledge will emerge out of these communities for al off the world to benefit Its fun to see chicken’s not only laying eggs but the manure regenerating the soil see native plants bear fruit see diversity coming back to

we are willing to build a World in which we all can experience this You a citizen of the World are part of this you are part of this calling you are part of this movement and this month is dedicated to celebrating this This is why today we want to talk about 3 ideas that must be in our minds some reminders for the Citizens of the World some tips to bring along for the walk  I hope this reflection gives you a little hope and that at the end of it just like me… you can declare yourself an optimist  I was born in Guatemala I’m in love with life with colors with art and with exploring and learning from this world I’m a firm believer that passion is what make things beautiful I’m interested in alternative education performing arts women empowerment and dogs I worked on the fashion industry for a while even though I love it I always felt I was lacking a why a purpose This is why I now work at Wakami telling stories and changing the reality of my country one character at a time Your personal

provide a safe space for girls to learn; they provide social capital for them in their villages and knowledge that will allow them to become their dream  We are also working with a program for young women leaders 18 to 22 called “She Impacts”  We learned this as I had had the opportunity to be a mentor for such a program in the US  We have done it now for 6 years and for the first time we did a Central American She Leads Program – girls from the region are being empowered connected and reassured in their dreams and that their roles are important  We also do entrepreneurship programs and a program called Get Women on Boards  We have become networks of women supporting each other growing together becoming empowered transforming reality alongside men that see the importance of the balance  As for me and my dream that women could have a source of income to make their dreams a reality – we continued to grow the Wakami System as a system that creates value chains in handmade products coffee

the planet The gifts women bring are so needed these days The leadership that women bring is so needed these days We need more peace more taking care of people and the Earth more collaboration than competition more empathy than polarization more US rather than more we and them As I write this it is the month where in the US the American Heart Association focuses our attention on women’s heart health and next month is Women’s History Month which includes International Women’s Day While we celebrate women all year long here at Wakami these two months are special A big part of the Wakami experience is to work with women to create healthy homes to help them understand nutrition so they can raise healthy children to provide pathways to education and to help them become leaders who will inspire others When we say every bracelet makes a difference it is more than putting money in the hands of women who were previously living in poverty It is much more Every purchase also helps fund the

Commerce & Products.question: What products, services, or technologies are available?
Commerce & Products.result: Based on the provided information, there are no specific details about the types of products, services, or technologies mentioned. However, it can be inferred that Wakami offers unique handcrafted items such as bags, jewelry, home decor, and textiles. These products are designed and created by indigenous Guatemalan artisans, empowering them through fair trade practices. Additionally, Wakami also operates physical stores where customers can purchase their products.

source.content: concepts designs and weaves new products creates the Wakami stores – and she tells the funniest stories She started with us fourteen years ago when Wakami was still just an idea and her input helped to shape our values and styles – so they run in her blood Lis is essential for the brand as Wakami is a very important piece of her life It’s funny Back then Lis had dreamed of designing electronic products that could reach the world Now look at today Little did she know that her designs would be sold all around the world but these products would be completely different to what she had imagined When Lis started at Wakami she had the task to develop products any product to reach the market and create opportunities for women in different communities in Guatemala all with different skill sets It was then that she started doing research on the best-selling products in the market products that could be made fast and in large quantities to open multiple opportunities for women in Guatemala Lis

all the time thinking analyzing and questioning Usually we do this with the design team and then we share our ideas to the Marketing and Sales Team This time we really did all this analyzing as a one big team We sat in Zoom meetings with at least one member of each team to discuss the concepts the ideas the products the price points the materials and the goals  The process was by itself a journey of understanding Now we are finally ready to start developing the samples and the products We have our mind and our values clear We now know what we are looking for in every single product we are creating and we know it’s non-negotiable That itself has been pretty refreshing Taking full responsibility for our actions and choices So for now that is what we have been up to Questioning Analyzing Just one last thing as I wrote on my last blog and as we have learned during all the Zoom meeting with the team when we come together and co-create magic happens So let us know what you would want to see

Commerce & Products.question: Are there any promotional events, expos, or sales for these offerings? If yes, list them.
Commerce & Products.result:
Yes, there are various promotional events, expos, and sales related to Wakami's offerings. Some of these include:

1. National Women's Month Celebration: During March, Wakami hosts events and promotions to celebrate National Women's Month. These events highlight the importance of empowering women through their products and provide opportunities for customers to learn more about Wakami's mission.
2. Online Sales & Promotions: Throughout the year, Wakami offers special discounts and promotions during holidays like Christmas, Mother's Day, and Father's Day. Additionally, they often host flash sales on social media platforms such as Instagram and Facebook. To stay updated on these exclusive deals, follow Wakami's official accounts on social media.
3. Pop-up Shops & Markets: From time to time, Wakami participates in pop-up shops and markets across Guatemala and other countries. These events allow customers to browse and purchase Wakami's unique products directly from the makers themselves. Keep an eye out for announcements regarding upcoming pop-up events near you.
4. Collaborations & Partnerships: Wakami sometimes collaborates with other brands, organizations, or influencers to promote their products and engage with new audiences. These partnerships may result in limited edition collections, exclusive promotions, or joint events. Be sure to check Wakami's official channels for news about recent collaborations.

products that could transform into opportunities and a source of income Now most of our bracelets use the macramé technique and are made by multiple groups of women in different regions of Guatemala The group from Magdalena Milpas Altas was one of those groups that didn’t have a strong traditional heritage They started with macramé and now know almost any technique in all of our products including traditional ones They work hand in hand with us to develop every product of our collection Just as I mentioned in my last post each day I realize the value and responsibility with each of our decisions we make in the process of designing a product Each product represents an opportunity And each opportunity can cause a dream to come true My name is Ana As a kid I traveled and moved constantly so the thought of home the landscapes and the people have deeply influenced me My work is about finding connections between traditional and contemporary practices It is about celebrating culture and

Commerce & Products.question: What are the key partnerships or collaborations related to commerce?
Commerce & Products.result: One significant collaboration for Wakami is with Puente Belice Project, which helps young Guatemalans complete their education while working alongside Wakami's teams. Additionally, Wakami works closely with its network of artisans, ensuring they receive fair compensation for their work and have access to resources that support their personal and professional growth. By fostering these relationships, Wakami is able to create positive social impact while also building a successful and sustainable business model.

source.content: We are a chain of actions that exist to create products that are invitations to live in a world of prosperity purpose and hope Get to know this trip The journey of our products begins when our team collects information from nature from ancient techniques from the world’s conversations and from this… a concept is born Our team then begins a dialogue with the different artisans we work with This process is sometimes a journey sometimes it is a call sometimes it is a coffee At this time we validate techniques and learn together with the artisans what is the best way to make our concept something real The materials reach the communities where the groups of artisans with whom we work live These materials are distributed to the different members of the group so that they can work on our products while being close to their families Our products are packed in Guatemala City and we do it in alliance with the Puente Belice project this allows young Guatemalans to finish their studies Our

listening to my team and to the different stakeholders with an open mind Similarly understanding their points of view and then deciding which steps to take next Read Full Article If you liked this interview go check out Maria’s interview with Esquire MY It’s about Wakami’s social impact and social consciousness If you liked this interview go check out Maria’s interview with Esquire MY It’s about Wakami’s social impact and social consciousness We work with artisans — 90 of whom are women—in remote areas of Guatemala and connect them with urban markets around the world Wakami products are what we call messengers of connection— changing the lives of those who produce them and enriching the lives of those who wear them  This relationship provides a sustainable source of income for the advancement of their families investment in their communities or reinvestment in their businesses Buenas tardes soy de Guatemala y elaboró un cuadro a mano nunca aunque este de más dejo de preguntar es algo

Employment & Opportunities.question: What employment or educational opportunities are currently available?
Employment & Opportunities.result: Based on the provided information, there isn't any specific mention of current employment or educational opportunities within the text. However, the organization mentioned seems to focus on empowering women through various programs, including "She Impacts" for young women leaders aged 18-22, and entrepreneurship programs. Additionally, the Wakami System creates value chains in handmade products, coffee, and dogs, which may offer potential job opportunities related to these industries.

in meaningful connections and we understand the power of trus love and respect for other citizens of the World  The invitation now is to find those Citizens of the World around you talk to them open your heart Connect with people that inspire you because that my friends is life’s purest and best gift I’m lucky to have met plenty of people with dreams like mine and this is why I think of myself as the richest person in the world  I was born in Guatemala I’m in love with life with colors with art and with exploring and learning from this world I’m a firm believer that passion is what make things beautiful I’m interested in alternative education performing arts women empowerment and dogs I worked on the fashion industry for a while even though I love it I always felt I was lacking a why a purpose This is why I now work at Wakami telling stories and changing the reality of my country one character at a time Your personal data will be used to support your experience throughout this website

Employment & Opportunities.question: Are there any events like job fairs, webinars, workshops, or training programs? If yes, list them.
Employment & Opportunities.result:
Yes, there are various events happening throughout the year related to job opportunities, professional development, and networking. Some examples include:

1. Job Fairs: These events bring together employers and job seekers under one roof. Examples include the annual Career Fair organized by Universidad del Valle de Guatemala (UVG) and similar events held by other universities and institutions.
2. Webinars: Online seminars or presentations conducted over the internet can cover a wide range of topics relevant to career growth and development. Companies, organizations, and educational institutions often host webinars on subjects such as interview skills, resume writing, industry trends, and technical expertise.
3. Workshops: Short courses or hands-on sessions focused on specific skills or areas of interest. These may be offered by educational institutions, NGOs, or private companies. Examples include coding bootcamps, marketing workshops, and leadership training.
4. Training Programs: Longer-term programs designed to develop specific skills or competencies. These may be provided by educational institutions, government agencies, or private sector organizations. Examples include apprenticeships, internships, and vocational training programs.
5. Networking Events: Opportunities for professionals to connect with one another and expand their professional circles. Examples include meetups, conferences, and industry-specific gatherings.

source.content: ways to improve our world  That is why we are so proud along other companies to be part of the B Corporation Movement  a movement that measures how companies perform at different levels – community environment customers… Wakami has been certified since  and was one of the first companies to be certified in Guatemala Back then very few people knew what being a B Corp meant For us it was wonderful to see there were others in the same journey as we were Now the world is looking for B Corps and their products and services knowing they each one have a unique purpose into how to create a better world starting with their own communities Through the certification process not only do they  evaluate your business you also learn of new ways in which others are creating change so being a B Corp is like going to school and learning not from a teacher but from your fellow students I invite you to see the B Corp site wwwbcorporationnet  One phrase reflects the philosophy behind this movement – The

provide a safe space for girls to learn; they provide social capital for them in their villages and knowledge that will allow them to become their dream  We are also working with a program for young women leaders 18 to 22 called “She Impacts”  We learned this as I had had the opportunity to be a mentor for such a program in the US  We have done it now for 6 years and for the first time we did a Central American She Leads Program – girls from the region are being empowered connected and reassured in their dreams and that their roles are important  We also do entrepreneurship programs and a program called Get Women on Boards  We have become networks of women supporting each other growing together becoming empowered transforming reality alongside men that see the importance of the balance  As for me and my dream that women could have a source of income to make their dreams a reality – we continued to grow the Wakami System as a system that creates value chains in handmade products coffee

all the time thinking analyzing and questioning Usually we do this with the design team and then we share our ideas to the Marketing and Sales Team This time we really did all this analyzing as a one big team We sat in Zoom meetings with at least one member of each team to discuss the concepts the ideas the products the price points the materials and the goals  The process was by itself a journey of understanding Now we are finally ready to start developing the samples and the products We have our mind and our values clear We now know what we are looking for in every single product we are creating and we know it’s non-negotiable That itself has been pretty refreshing Taking full responsibility for our actions and choices So for now that is what we have been up to Questioning Analyzing Just one last thing as I wrote on my last blog and as we have learned during all the Zoom meeting with the team when we come together and co-create magic happens So let us know what you would want to see

source.content: all the time thinking analyzing and questioning Usually we do this with the design team and then we share our ideas to the Marketing and Sales Team This time we really did all this analyzing as a one big team We sat in Zoom meetings with at least one member of each team to discuss the concepts the ideas the products the price points the materials and the goals  The process was by itself a journey of understanding Now we are finally ready to start developing the samples and the products We have our mind and our values clear We now know what we are looking for in every single product we are creating and we know it’s non-negotiable That itself has been pretty refreshing Taking full responsibility for our actions and choices So for now that is what we have been up to Questioning Analyzing Just one last thing as I wrote on my last blog and as we have learned during all the Zoom meeting with the team when we come together and co-create magic happens So let us know what you would want to see

Our re-certification as a B-Corp has caused me to reflect on our markets our vision and our mission I have always seen the power of markets – and their ability to transform realities And I have learned that markets that value the ancestral legacies recover ecosystems and give opportunities to people that have been excluded are markets that create a beautiful world These are the beliefs we have in Wakami  – our vision is in creating a beautiful world where both the people and the Earth are happy; creating products that inspire our customers and transform the lives of the people that produce them is our mission Easier said than done We have learned at Wakami that more than a destination this vision and mission are like the fences that signal the road to travel are what keep us moving – through falls through celebrations through hard times through VERY hard times    This vision though is so strong so that the road is worth taking Like I have shared many times with many of you and as you

travellers and other precious stakeholders that have been part of the journey I am one of those priviledged people that the dream has not just transformed but totally taken over One of our board members Juan Carlos Paiz said once to me- “Maria Wakami will be stronger when it is not only set up to transform others – like rural communities – but also ourselves also you  When Wakami is set up to transform you as well that is when real strength will come from” Juan Carlos has always challenged me  I did not quite get it then or knew how to go about it but he was so right The Wakami dream has been twitched lately and not by me but my Ana the Wakami creative director who is my daughter as well – with the end result of being all inclusive for people that dream of a better world After one day of visiting rural communities with her some in which we were looking at Maguey – a natural fiber – being harvested and processed and turned into a bag and another community where we were looking at

for me and my dream that women could have a source of income to make their dreams a reality – we continued to grow the Wakami System as a system that creates value chains in handmade products coffee and regenerative agriculture    This system connects women mostly in rural communities – to local national and international markets  We have created a system where we can produce high volume high quality products bracelets bags clothes home décor that are sold nationally and exported around the world and that created constant sources of income for women  We are now celebrating Wakami children graduating not just from high school but from college in a country where the average school attendance is 45 years And 60 of children that come into the system with chronic malnutrition start recovering 1 year after their mothers begin generating income through Wakami in a country with 50 malnutrition We are making collective change through key partnerships that complement what we do with

Research & Innovation.question: What are the latest publications, research findings, or introduced technologies?
Research & Innovation.result: Based on the provided information, it seems like the focus has been on alternative methods for producing food and leather goods without killing animals. One such method mentioned is "biofabricating" meat and leather through tissue engineering. Additionally, there has been collaboration among various teams within the company to ensure they create products aligned with their values and goals. However, no specific publication, research finding, or introduced technology has been directly mentioned or linked to in the text.

plastic because of the nano plastic particles that spread every time we wash the product Then I found some pretty amazing innovative materials but then again they are still not available for common use A bit frustrated I returned to the team at Wakami for some guidance I started talking with Maria our founder and while talking about Wakami our goals strategies and sustainability the word family kept coming up We at Wakami as a company our goal is not to be sustainable or have sustainable products but rather have sustainable families Still all our questions were not clear But this time instead of going outside for answers we decided to look in to go back to the communities We went to Jocotán to visit a pilot project on regenerative agriculture run by Comunidades de la Tierra our sister NGO The goal for this project is to have sustainable families while balancing the ecosystem Taking care of the earth while it takes care of us In this pilot project the families start with chickens and

This  month I was in Washington DC with the privilege of sharing a stage with Sec Hillary Clinton and 4 other powerful and dedicated women  It brought me back 17 years when I first sat a table like this     We were also in Washington DC  As I shared my dream for Guatemala one in which women would have a source of income to make their dreams a reality one where they would not have to choose which child to try to save or which child to try to send to school – I started tearing up I felt so heard so seen so relieved It was  There were 18 women coming together from different part of the World for the First Vital Voices Fortune/State Department Mentorship Program Joining us were women from the United States from Fortune  Companies from the US State Department and from Vital Voices    For the first time in a long time I no longer felt alone in my dream  And all of a sudden it was like the weight of this dream got lighter  I realized all the women sitting at that table had similar dreams some

Collaboration & Partnerships.question: What organizations, institutions, or entities is the organization collaborating with?
Collaboration & Partnerships.result:
Based on the provided information, the organization is working closely with several partners. These include:

1. Communities of the Earth (COTE): A Guatemalan non-profit that implements the methodologies supported by the organization. They are responsible for implementing the programs in various regions across Guatemala.
2. B Corporation (B Corp) Movement: The organization encourages collaboration within the B Corp network, which is based on the Declaration of Interdependence. By being part of this movement, they aim to promote cooperation and shared goals among like-minded companies.
3. Wakami Foundation: The organization operates under the umbrella of the Wakami Foundation, a c3 organization focusing on improving the lives of rural women and their families. Together, they strive to break cycles of poverty and foster prosperity in Guatemalan communities.

source.content: According to dictionarycom the first definition is “a body of persons entrusted with a mission to a sovereign or government” As we use the term our meaning is a little different  We see our embassy as  “a body of persons entrusted with a mission to each other and their community We recently opened our first Wakami Embassy and its mission is to create a space to connect with each other and the community My story with communities goes way back As I have shared before I am a biologist  I love the Earth I want its rivers to be clean its oceans to be intact the land to be full of forests and jungle and native plants and animals to be everywhere 30 years ago as I was graduating with my Masters degree in Agriculture my journey took me deep into the ecosystems I cared so much about and even while I loved the lushness and vitality of many of the places I visited I also saw ecosystems stripped of all of lushness all vitality – suffering It was in those harshest of places that I found inspiration

going to school and learning not from a teacher but from your fellow students I invite you to see the B Corp site wwwbcorporationnet  One phrase reflects the philosophy behind this movement – The Declaration of Interdependence which is the basis for the movement You can find out listing right here  This crisis has shown we are all connected B Corps acknowledge not only that we are connected but that cooperation is at the heart of change and hope I had the opportunity to meet one of its founders Jay Coen Gilbert and when he shared his own personal story that lead him to start this movement along Bart Houlahan and Andrew Kassoy I was really inspired For Wakami it is very special to know we are together with others creating these new ways for the world  To be part of a community that shares so many values is priceless for us My name is María I was born in Guatemala and I am a biologist an entrepreneur and founder of the Wakami system I am also a mother and a firm believer that collective

Wakami Foundation is a c3 organization that focuses primarily on the lives of rural women and their struggle to generate sources of income for their families We support business training to these rural women in order to transform cycles of poverty into cycles of prosperity Currently we support work in rural communities of Guatemala with two methodologies Which incubates establishes and strengthens rural businesses mainly led by women through nine training cycles conducted over a two-year time span A platform that provides access to products and services to these women – allowing rural families to invest their income strategically in order to improve their homes and their children’s education and nutrition Currently our support is focused on more than 8 Guatemalan regions Our partner on the ground in these areas is Communities of the Earth “COTE” a Guatemalan non-profit that implements the methodologies that we support Currently our support is focused on more than 8 Guatemalan regions

the one we create when we work together In the Wakami Embassy there are workshops where people from the villages share their experiences with travelers from other parts of the world  It’s the hub for different trainings so communities can access different value chains that require different skills It’s the place to be a part of a circle of light or a finding your purpose workshop  It is a place to buy products that carry the energy of hope  It’s a place to just be Welcome to this home away from home  Bring your dream with you  And enter… My name is María I was born in Guatemala and I am a biologist an entrepreneur and founder of the Wakami system I am also a mother and a firm believer that collective dreams are unstoppable My life’s work has been to find ways to link people who are stuck in cycles of poverty to markets that can create cycles of prosperity Your personal data will be used to support your experience throughout this website to manage access to your account and for other

Collaboration & Partnerships.question: Are there any joint events, projects, or initiatives? If yes then list them.
Collaboration & Partnerships.result:
Yes, there are several joint events, projects, and initiatives involving Maria Marquez and her organization, Wakami. Some notable collaborations include:

1. B Corp Site Visit: Maria invited readers to visit the B Corp website (www[dot]bcorporation[dot]net) after mentioning the Declaration of Interdependence as the foundation of the movement.
2. Social Impact and Consciousness: In another interview, Maria discussed Wakami's social impact and social consciousness. They work closely with artisans, primarily women, in remote areas of Guatemala, connecting them with urban markets around the world.
3. Collaborative Process: When developing new products, Maria mentioned that her team works collaboratively, including members from various departments like design, marketing, and sales. They recently completed a thorough analysis process, ensuring that all teams were aligned in their vision and values.
4. Girls Education and Empowerment: Wakami supports programs focused on education and empowerment for girls, providing them with opportunities to develop essential skills and pursue their dreams. These programs include "She Impacts" and "Get Women on Boards."
5. Regional Empowerment Program: Maria participated in a regional She Leads Program, aimed at empowering and connecting young women leaders across Central America.

These joint events, projects, and initiatives demonstrate Maria Marquez's commitment to collaboration and making a positive impact within her community and beyond.

listening to my team and to the different stakeholders with an open mind Similarly understanding their points of view and then deciding which steps to take next Read Full Article If you liked this interview go check out Maria’s interview with Esquire MY It’s about Wakami’s social impact and social consciousness If you liked this interview go check out Maria’s interview with Esquire MY It’s about Wakami’s social impact and social consciousness We work with artisans — 90 of whom are women—in remote areas of Guatemala and connect them with urban markets around the world Wakami products are what we call messengers of connection— changing the lives of those who produce them and enriching the lives of those who wear them  This relationship provides a sustainable source of income for the advancement of their families investment in their communities or reinvestment in their businesses Buenas tardes soy de Guatemala y elaboró un cuadro a mano nunca aunque este de más dejo de preguntar es algo

all the time thinking analyzing and questioning Usually we do this with the design team and then we share our ideas to the Marketing and Sales Team This time we really did all this analyzing as a one big team We sat in Zoom meetings with at least one member of each team to discuss the concepts the ideas the products the price points the materials and the goals  The process was by itself a journey of understanding Now we are finally ready to start developing the samples and the products We have our mind and our values clear We now know what we are looking for in every single product we are creating and we know it’s non-negotiable That itself has been pretty refreshing Taking full responsibility for our actions and choices So for now that is what we have been up to Questioning Analyzing Just one last thing as I wrote on my last blog and as we have learned during all the Zoom meeting with the team when we come together and co-create magic happens So let us know what you would want to see

provide a safe space for girls to learn; they provide social capital for them in their villages and knowledge that will allow them to become their dream  We are also working with a program for young women leaders 18 to 22 called “She Impacts”  We learned this as I had had the opportunity to be a mentor for such a program in the US  We have done it now for 6 years and for the first time we did a Central American She Leads Program – girls from the region are being empowered connected and reassured in their dreams and that their roles are important  We also do entrepreneurship programs and a program called Get Women on Boards  We have become networks of women supporting each other growing together becoming empowered transforming reality alongside men that see the importance of the balance  As for me and my dream that women could have a source of income to make their dreams a reality – we continued to grow the Wakami System as a system that creates value chains in handmade products coffee

Collaboration & Partnerships.question: What are the mutual objectives and outcomes expected from these collaborations?
Collaboration & Partnerships.result:
Through their collaborative efforts, the teams involved aim to achieve several common objectives and desired outcomes. These include:

1. Developing innovative products: By working together, the different teams can combine their expertise to create unique and high-quality products that cater to diverse customer needs and preferences.
2. Enhancing marketing strategies: Collaboration allows the various teams to exchange insights and ideas, ultimately improving their ability to reach target audiences effectively through marketing campaigns and promotional activities.
3. Optimizing sales performance: When multiple teams collaborate, they can better understand consumer behavior, identify trends, and adapt their sales tactics accordingly, leading to improved overall sales figures.
4. Strengthening brand identity: Joint efforts among the design, marketing, and sales teams help reinforce the company's core values, mission, and vision, ensuring a consistent and strong brand image across all touchpoints.
5. Improving operational efficiency: Collaboration enables the teams to streamline processes, share resources, and optimize workflows, resulting in increased productivity and cost savings.
6. Fostering a positive company culture: By working closely together, the teams can develop a stronger sense of unity, trust, and camaraderie, contributing to a more enjoyable and fulfilling work environment.
7. Achieving business growth: Ultimately, the combined efforts of the various teams are intended to drive business success, including revenue growth, market expansion, and increased market share.

one last thing as I wrote on my last blog and as we have learned during all the Zoom meeting with the team when we come together and co-create magic happens So let us know what you would want to see What is that you need as a citizen of the world  How would you like to co-create with us My name is Ana As a kid I traveled and moved constantly so the thought of home the landscapes and the people have deeply influenced me My work is about finding connections between traditional and contemporary practices It is about celebrating culture and community It is about finding new ways to work together and collaborate My life has always been intertwined with Wakami but now they intersect in a place where change can occur by designing and creating Your personal data will be used to support your experience throughout this website to manage access to your account and for other purposes described in our privacy policy
